explanation:
To check for use of language/compiler extensions in OS_mkdir you must inspect the actual declarations/definitions of the identifiers used in the function so any extension tokens (e.g. __attribute__, asm, typeof, statement-expr, compiler-specific calling conventions) or non-constant expressions (which could cause a VLA) are visible: 

- typedef/definition of int32: verify this is a standard typedef (e.g. from stdint.h or a plain typedef) and does not use compiler-specific type extensions (e.g. built-in __int128, compiler-specific modifiers).

- typedef/definition of uint32: same reason as int32.

- definition (macro/enum) of OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN: the array local_path uses this identifier as its size. If this is not a compile-time constant (or is defined via a compiler-specific construct) the local array might be a variable-length array or rely on extensions. You need the macro/enum value or its definition to determine whether a language extension is required.

- definition (macro/enum) of OS_SUCCESS: used in the comparison. If OS_SUCCESS is defined via a compiler extension or uses unusual syntax, that could be a violation; confirm it is a plain macro/enum/integer constant.

- prototype/definition (or macro) of OS_TranslatePath: the call site may be a macro that expands to compiler-specific constructs or its prototype may carry attributes (e.g. __attribute__((...))) or other extensions. Inspect its declaration/definition to ensure no language extensions are used.

- prototype/definition (or macro) of OS_DirCreate_Impl: same rationale as OS_TranslatePath — the symbol might be a macro or have an annotated prototype using compiler-specific extensions that would make the call site rely on an extension.

Collecting these symbol definitions/prototypes lets the analyzer determine whether the target function itself uses any language extensions (through types, array sizing, macros, or called-declaration attributes).
